title: Reflections on Macroeconomics Then and Now
content: Kaldor’s Stylized Facts 1. The shares of national income received by labor and capital are  roughly constant over long periods of time.  2. The rate of growth of the capital stock per worker is roughly constant  over long periods of time.  3. The rate of growth of output per worker is roughly constant over long  periods of time.  4. The capital/output ratio is roughly constant over long periods of time.  5. The rate of return on investment is roughly constant over long periods  of time.  6. The real wage grows over time.  Source:  Nicholas Kaldor (1957), “A Model of Economic Growth,” Economic Journal, vol. 67 (December), pp. 591–624.
